stem: The nurse is caring for a confused client who requires bilateral soft wrist restraints to prevent the removal of a central venous catheter. Indicate whether each nursing action is appropriate or inappropriate according to safety standards.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
21:00: Client (82y/o female) is increasingly agitated and disoriented to time and place. She has attempted to pull out her right-arm PICC line three times in the last hour. 
21:15: Re-orientation and a family sitter were unsuccessful in calming the client. 
21:30: Soft wrist restraints applied as a last resort to maintain tube/line safety. Provider notified and emergency order obtained. 
22:00: Client pulling against restraints; skin remains intact.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Neuro: Oriented to person only. Picking at dressings. 
Skin: Radial pulses 2+ bilaterally. Fingers are pink and warm. 
Musculoskeletal: Active range of motion in all extremities prior to restraint application.

tabs.title: Hospital Policy
tabs.content: Restraint orders for non-behavioral (medical/surgical) safety must be renewed every 24 hours. Physical assessment and documentation of circulation, skin integrity, and range of motion must occur every 2 hours.

rows.text: Securing the restraint ties to the movable part of the bed frame
Ensuring the restraint is tight enough that no fingers can fit between the skin and the strap
Securing the restraint ties to the side rails for easy access
Performing a neurovascular assessment and offering toileting every 2 hours
Using a quick-release knot to secure the restraint
Obtaining a new written order every 48 hours for continued use

rationale.correct: Restraints must be tied to the **bed frame** (r1), not the side rails (r3), because side rails move and can cause injury. Two fingers should fit between the restraint and the client (r2) to prevent neurovascular impairment. Checks must occur every 2 hours (r4) and a quick-release knot is required for emergencies (r5). Orders for medical safety must be renewed every **24 hours**, not 48 hours (r6).
clinicalPearls: Never tie a restraint to a side rail. When the rail is lowered, the restraint can pull or fracture the client's limb.
Restraints are always the LAST resort. Try 'Sitter, Re-orientation, Bed Alarms' first.
PRN (as needed) orders for restraints are strictly prohibited.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that restraints should be 'tight' for better safety.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember the '2 Finger Rule'. If it's too tight, you risk compartment syndrome or tissue necrosis.

mnemonic.title: Restraint Rules
mnemonic.expansion: F-Frame (Tie to it), R-Release (Quick knot), E-Every 2 hours (Checks), E-Every 24 (Renewal).
